name: AddMediaInformationFlows
description: Use an HTML search report file from Lexis Nexis and quantify spatial dissemination of information in the form of publications, news, etc.

inputParams.name: Administrative_Layer
inputParams.description: An OGR-supported shapefile or Feature Layer corresponding to the geographic locations (e.g. countries) you are interested in searching within the media report file.
inputParams.label: Administrative Layer

inputParams.name: Location_Field
inputParams.description: A field in the input feature layer that will be used as a geographic location to search within the media report file.
inputParams.label: Location Field

inputParams.name: Media_Report_File
inputParams.description: An HTML file created from a word search on the online LexisNexis portal.
inputParams.label: Media Report File (html)

inputParams.name: Source_Location
inputParams.description: Select on the map the geographic location from which information has emanated out. This location should correspond to the term used to search through the LexisNexis online database. NOTE: Make sure to select ONLY a SINGLE source location on the map.
inputParams.label: Source Location

inputParams.name: Merge_With_Existing_Flow_Layer
inputParams.description: If checked (default), radial flows generated from the media report file will be merged to an existing OGR-supported shapefile or Feature Layer corresponding to other flows of information.
inputParams.label: Merge With Existing Flow Layer (optional)

inputParams.name: Input_Flow_Layer
inputParams.description: An optional feature layer representing existing radial flows of information that will be merged with the flows layer generated from the media report file. For example, you may have already generated radial flows of information generated by movement of tourists between sending and receiving systems.
inputParams.label: Input Flow Layer (optional)

inputParams.name: Line_Type
inputParams.description: The type of geodetic line to construct.GEODESIC— A type of geodetic line which most accurately represents the shortest distance between any two points on the surface of the earth. The mathematical definition of the geodesic line is quite lengthy and complex and therefore omitted here. This line type is the default. GREAT_CIRCLE—A type of geodetic line which represents the path between any two points along the intersection of the surface of the earth and a plane that passes through the center of the earth. Depending on the output coordinate system specified by the Spatial Reference parameter, in a spheroid-based coordinate system, the line is a great elliptic; in a sphere-based coordinate system, the line is uniquely called a great circle—a circle of the largest radius on the spherical surface. RHUMB_LINE—A type of geodetic line, also known as a loxodrome line, which represents a path between any two points on the surface of a spheroid defined by a constant azimuth from a pole. A rhumb line is shown as a straight line in the Mercator projection. NORMAL_SECTION—A type of geodetic line which represents a path between any two points on the surface of a spheroid defined by the intersection of the spheroid surface and a plane that passes through the two points and is normal (perpendicular) to the spheroid surface at the starting point of the two points. Therefore, the normal section line from point A to point B is different from the one from point B to point A.
inputParams.label: Line Type (optional)
